comment.author: 10564098@N08
comment._content:
I agree about the name but is bad writing. The right way to write this last name is  "Orozco".

Maybe an american or a poor educated man write this in the original's negative.
Alejandro Joya from México

comment.author: 28986958@N08
comment._content: Correct spelling is "Orozco", for General Pascual Orozco, one of Pancho Villa's closests. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pascual_Orozco I work in that building in the left, which today is a museum. Actually, my office is the best-seen window in the pic.

comment.author: 57881542@N03
comment._content:
Gusmac,

Several accounts has his name spelled Orosco.  The person that documented the picture may have been familiar with both spellings and just decided to use both.  Interesting that the building is still there.  I would like to see it some day.

Juan Orosco

comment.author: 53461717@N08
comment._content:
El 26 enero de 1912 Orozco escribe una carta a Madero donde renuncia a su cargo para dedicarse a sus "actividades privadas". Entre enero y febrero conspira con la oligarquía de Chihuahua en contra de Madero y lanza su Plan de la Empacadora [fechaddo el 6 de marzo de 1912] en el que desconoce el gobierno de Madero acusándolo de traicionar la Revolución y el Plan de San Luis.  Con este levantamiento se apodera del Estado de Chihuahua y esta foto muestra su entrada triunfal a esa capital.
Dr. Roberto Duarte

comment.author: 35234565@N04
comment._content: Thank you, Dr. Duarte for connecting the two images.   We'll make the corrections, and add the date to the other image the next time we update.
